review.title: Model checking coalitional games in shortage resource scenarios
review.abstract: Verification of multi-agents systems (MAS) has been recently studied taking into account the need of expressing resource bounds. Several logics for specifying properties of MAS have been presented in quite a variety of scenarios with bounded resources. In this paper, we study a different formalism, called Priced Resource-Bounded Alternating-time Temporal Logic (PRBATL), whose main novelty consists in moving the notion of resources from a syntactic level (part of the formula) to a semantic one (part of the model). This allows us to track the evolution of the resource availability along the computations and provides us with a formalisms capable to model a number of real-world scenarios. Two relevant aspects are the notion of global availability of the resources on the market, that are shared by the agents, and the notion of price of resources, depending on their availability. In a previous work of ours, an initial step towards this new formalism was introduced, along with an EXPTIME algorithm for the model checking problem. In this paper we better analyze the features of the proposed formalism, also in comparison with previous approaches. The main technical contribution is the proof of the EXPTIME-hardness of the the model checking problem for PRBATL, based on a reduction from the acceptance problem for Linearly-Bounded Alternating Turing Machines. In particular, since the problem has multiple parameters, we show two fixed-parameter reductions.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Most of the research is based on logical formalities and is used as specification languages for open systems. Therefore, these scenarios are naturally modelled as games. [10] it has been shown that CL can be embedded in ATL. Lately, these two logics have been used for the verification of multi-agent systems (MAS), reinforced with resource constraints. The intuitive idea is that agent actions consume and / or produce resources, i.e. the choice of a given action by an agent is subject to the availability of resources.

sections.heading: 2 Comparison with related works

sections.heading: 4 Complexity lower bounds for the model checking problem
sections.text: In [9], the authors presented an algorithm for model verification PRB-ATL, which provides an exponential upper limit for the problem. Let n be the number of agents, r be the number of resources, and M be the maximum component that occurs in the initial resource availability vector, the proposed algorithm runs exponentially in n, r, and the size of the representation of M (assuming M is represented in binary form). In this section, we will demonstrate that an algorithm that behaves asymptotically better cannot exist, thereby proving that the problem is EXPTIME-complete. To prove the inherent difficulty in relation to the multiple input parameters, we will show two reductions: a parametric one in the representation of M (the digit size) that assumes both n and r-constant, and the other parametric one in r, this time assuming constant and the value M. We will assume the existence of an EXPIME-two, and the problem of an EXPIME-two, the EXPIME-two is suggested for the fact in the PRATE-two.

sections.heading: 4.1 Linearly-bounded alternating Turing Machines
sections.text: A linear interchangeable configuration of Turing machines (LB-ATM) is a tuple < Q, Q, Q, Q, I, q0, >, where Q is the set of states divided into Q (universal states) and Q "(existential states), is the set of tape symbols, including the" blank "symbol B and two special symbols x and y, whose first and last cell separates the left and right ribbons; a tape configuration is a sequence of symbols stored in the tape cells, and the symbols from the first and last cell of tape storage are respectively the symbols x and y." A tape configuration is a sequence of symbols stored in the tape cells and keeps the track of a header cell. A configuration c is a pair (q, s) of a state q and a configuration of the configuration of the configurations.

sections.heading: 4.3 Another reduction.
sections.text: As noted at the beginning of Section 4, it is possible to show two further reductions on the tape, due to which two parameters out of three are assumed to be constant. In the following, we briefly outline how to achieve a reduction in the acceptance problem for LB-ATM if n and M. This reduction is easier than the previous one. Here, the encoding of the tape is achieved by means of a number of resources linearly in the length of the tape. Let's check the length of the tape, we use 2 sets of | s | resource variables, namely µ1L, µ2L,.., µ | L and µ1R, µ2R,..., µ | s | R, plus the resource variable µ. Each variable encodes the content of a tape cell: Variable µ encodes the content of the header cell, while for each i the variable µ iL (or µ iR) represents the value.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a formalism that is very suitable for modeling the characteristics of multi-agent systems when agents share resources and the need to avoid unlimited consumption of such resources is crucial. < Within our framework, it is possible to track the traces of a real global availability of resources used by both proponents and opponents, thus avoiding unrealistic situations in which an unlimited amount of resources is used in a game. < The technical focus of the paper is on the complexity of the problem of model verification, and we have proven that it is EXPTIME complete (remember that even for simpler formalism, this problem exists in EXPTIME, although the lower limit is not known). Other problems of interest exist in the context of verifying the multi-agent system. The most important is the problem of accessibility, which is the problem of determining whether a team, with a given amount of money and a given global strategy, has the ability to implement a given resource.

referenceMentions.context: Verification of multi-agents systems (MAS) is a topic under investigation by several research groups in computer science in the last ten years ([8]).

Most of the research is based on logical formalisms, maybe the most famous being the Alternating-time Temporal Logics (ATL) [3] and the Coalition Logic (CL) [15, 16], both oriented towards the description of collective behaviors and used as specification languages for open systems.

As a further difference, recall that in [2] actions can only consume resources.
Bulling and Farwer [6] adopted an “horizontal” approach, in the sense that they explored a large number of variants of a formalism to model these complex systems.
However, our approach presents conceptual novelties that make it difficult to accomplish a direct comparisons between the formalisms presented here and the ones proposed in [6].
In [6], there is no such a notion as resources are assigned to (team of) agents and proponent and opponent do not compete for their acquisition.

As regards the complexity issue, in [6], no complexity analysis (for the model checking problem) is performed, while, in [2], an upper bound is given for RB-ATL, that matches the one given in [9] for PRB-ATL.

We first recall the formalism of linearly-bounded alternating Turing machines (LB-ATM) and the notion of hierarchical representation, a succinct way of representing priced game structures inspired to the work done in [4] for classical Kripke structures.
In order to exhibit our encoding proposal, we make use of a hierarchical representation analogous to the one described in [4, 12, 13] for model checking, and in [14] for module checking procedures.

The reachability problem is indeed NP-hard in this case: it immediately follows from a result in [11], when the number of agents is not constant.
The model checking problem, instead, turns out to be PSPACE-hard, since the reduction from QBF problem given in [9] works also in this case, when actions cannot produce resources.
Finally, we want to note that also the more general problem, called optimal coalition problem, is EXPTIME-complete (the upper bound was shown in [9]).

metadata.abstractText: Verification of multi-agents systems (MAS) has been recently studied taking into account the need of expressing resource bounds. Several logics for specifying properties of MAS have been presented in quite a variety of scenarios with bounded resources. In this paper, we study a different formalism, called Priced Resource-Bounded Alternating-time Temporal Logic (PRB-ATL), whose main novelty consists in moving the notion of resources from a syntactic level (part of the formula) to a semantic one (part of the model). This allows us to track the evolution of the resource availability along the computations and provides us with a formalisms capable to model a number of real-world scenarios. Two relevant aspects are the notion of global availability of the resources on the market, that are shared by the agents, and the notion of price of resources, depending on their availability. In a previous work of ours, an initial step towards this new formalism was introduced, along with an EXPTIME algorithm for the model checking problem. In this paper we better analyze the features of the proposed formalism, also in comparison with previous approaches. The main technical contribution is the proof of the EXPTIME-hardness of the the model checking problem for PRB-ATL, based on a reduction from the acceptance problem for Linearly-Bounded Alternating Turing Machines. In particular, since the problem has multiple parameters, we show two fixed-parameter reductions.
